stream_context.summary: Kaze debugs and iterates on the Raphael-the-Raven moon boss for Return to Yoshi’s Island, fixing a hitbox scaling bug, tuning difficulty, scripting the cutscene that catapults Mario to the moon, and deciding to spawn the star on the moon instead of programming a return pipe. He also outlines hub-world plans, notes the game is ~80 % complete, and discusses video editing, community pressure, and personal bureaucracy stress.

development_findings.summary: A scale change shrank Raphael’s model so far that the hurtbox became size 0, making hits register incorrectly; restoring an appropriate scale fixed the issue.
development_findings.quote: The scale of Raphael Raven was too small. He was scaling down so far that his hitbox was 0.

development_findings.summary: Each successful hit now increases Raphael’s size, making him easier to hit while also increasing speed and shock-wave frequency for tension balance.
Difficulty will gradually decrease over time (enemy slows after shockwaves) rather than adjust to Mario’s health, because Kaze dislikes level-scaling systems.
development_findings.quote: Time pretty much corresponds to how much trouble the user is having and I don't want to make it scale to health like RPG enemies.

development_findings.summary: Cutscene logic: Raphael blocks the moon, then jumps and flips gravity sending Mario to a small moon arena; camera paths are being hand-tuned by trial and error.
Zeina has delivered animation sets but they are not yet wired; placeholders are currently used for death and hit reactions.
Egg, pipe and star require planet-relative transforms; quaternion math is used to keep objects fixed to the spherical surface.
development_findings.quote: If you watch my newest video and you know a little bit about quaternions you can do this too.

development_findings.summary: Original plan to spawn a pipe for Mario’s return proved math-heavy; pivoted to simply spawning the star on the moon and ending the level there.
development_findings.quote: I'm just gonna spawn the star on top of the moon. I think that's the easiest way to do it.

development_findings.summary: Hub world (Yoshi’s Island) will feature coin-driven progression such as paying NPCs to build bridges or grow trees that open new paths.

development_findings.quote: What if the game is done? ... just over 80 percent.

development_findings.summary: ROM size is ~62 MB mainly due to streamed music; without streamed tracks it would be ~12 MB.
Kaze added an L-button cheat to instantly kill the boss for testing and future speedrun practice.

context_findings.summary: Kaze rates his current mental pain as ‘8’ due to bureaucracy, showing real-life stress impacting development.
context_findings.quote: I'm in mental pain because of bureaucracy.

context_findings.summary: He is frustrated with constant questions about release dates and plans to answer them with a lowercase ‘xd’.
context_findings.quote: The most fucked up part about being a famous rom-maker is when people harass me about the release date ... I will just respond with a lowercase xd.

context_findings.summary: Kaze observes polarized community feedback on difficulty—some say levels are for babies, others say they’re too hard.
context_findings.quote: No one ever says 'Kaze, the difficulty of this looks perfect to me'.

context_findings.summary: He works full-time as a video-game programmer and funds a video editor (Okayo) to improve YouTube output, aiming to earn more for his family.
Kaze values physical fitness and jokes about having ‘perfect skin’, revealing small personal quirks.

biobak.summary: Suggested rotating background during the boss fight and blocking the moon for a dramatic reveal; Kaze agrees it could look ‘so fucking cool’.
biobak.quote: Biobak, you can make this fight look so fucking cool with the background. Imagine the whole background here just rotating around.

zeina.summary: Modeled the meteors and is preparing full animation sets for Raphael and cutscenes.
zeina.quote: I think Zeina made it; I just made some small changes to make sure it works better here.

zeina.summary: Sent new animations near stream end; integration deferred to next session.
zeina.quote: You sent the animations ... unfortunately that's gonna be a next time thing because it's getting late.

key_stories.title: Hitbox Vanishes
key_stories.summary: A visual rescale inadvertently reduced Raphael’s hurtbox to zero, making the boss invulnerable. Kaze traced the issue to the scale factor and restored a workable size.
key_stories.challenge: Boss could no longer be damaged after recent edits.
key_stories.process: Printed Y-positions, inspected distance logs, realized scale affected collision bounds.
key_stories.outcome: Correct scale restored; boss damage detection works again.
key_stories.key_quote: The scale of Raphael Raven was too small. He was scaling down so far that his hitbox was 0.

key_stories.title: The Pipe That Wasn’t
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted a pipe to appear on the moon to return Mario to the tower, but quaternion-to-Euler math for proper orientation proved messy.
key_stories.challenge: Aligning a cylindrical pipe so it points away from the spherical moon surface.
key_stories.process: Tried deriving pitch/yaw from planet vectors, experimented with rotation order, faced crashes and misalignment.
key_stories.outcome: Abandoned the pipe; decided to hatch the star directly on the moon instead.
key_stories.key_quote: The pipe sucks—programming-wise and visually. I'm just gonna spawn the star on top of the moon.

key_stories.title: Balancing Raven Difficulty
key_stories.summary: Play-testing showed the fight oscillated between trivial and brutal. Kaze designed a scaling system where Raven speeds up with hits but overall slows over time.
key_stories.challenge: Finding a fair difficulty curve for varied player skill.
key_stories.process: Tested velocities, added speed increments and shock-wave frequency, then implemented time-based slowdown.
key_stories.outcome: Fight now starts tense but guarantees eventual victory; still subject to fine-tuning.
key_stories.key_quote: We make it slower the longer the fight goes. That way, everyone is guaranteed to beat it eventually.

key_stories.title: Community Pressure on Release Date
key_stories.summary: Persistent queries about launch timing irritate Kaze.
key_stories.challenge: Managing fan impatience without derailing morale.
key_stories.process: Decided on a humorous auto-response (‘xd’) and encourages chat to laugh off such questions.
key_stories.outcome: Sets a boundary while keeping tone light.
key_stories.key_quote: When people harass me about the release date ... I will just respond with a lowercase xd.
